titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Records of The Bolivia Project RISM RG 8
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Ulla S. Holmequist and Ani Rivera. Processed with new finding aid by Emilyn L. Brown and Hillina Seife, June 2006.

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from Guide to Bolivia Project.doc

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-03-04T11:58-0500

change.item: Revised by Janet Bunde, April 2009. Inventory revised by Julianna Monjeau and Ashley Levine, October 2010

did.abstract: The RISM Bolivia Project was initiated in 1964 at the request of the U.S. Peace Corps. Headed by Dr. Vera D. Rubin, founder and director of RISM, and Dr. Lambros Comitas, assistant director of RISM, anthropological and epidemiological teams studied six ecologically distinct communities in order to identify major health problems and to assess the implications of rural social organization to facilitate the work of development agencies. The Bolivia Project generated thousands of documents, including correspondence, accounting records, indexed field notes, laboratory processing records, surveys and questionnaires, epidemiological data, maps, photographs, microfiche and microfilm. The collection also includes appended items from an exhibition, Retrospect and Prospect: Preservation and Use of Archival Materials in the Digital Age, which celebrated the Bolivia Project. Appended items include exhibit brochures, information panels, oversized computer generated charts, and video tapes.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Research Institute for the Study of Man (RISM).

list.head: Arrangement
list.item: Appendix: Reports from RISM to the Peace Corps, Partial Reports Related to the RISM Bolivia Project, 1964-1967

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: No materials have been removed from the collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Bolivia Project (1964-1967) consists of 200 linear feet of materials, including correspondence, accounting records, biographical index cards, indexed field notes, epidemiological and ethnographic studies and reports, laboratory processing records and results, blood typing cards, health questionnaires, computer generated charts, questionnaires and surveys that focus on household sanitation data and investigation of infant feeding habits, community censuses, maps, oversized charts, microfiche, microfilm, articles, unpublished manuscripts and accounting records, photographs, and videotapes. Material from a 1997 exhibit, Retrospect and Prospect: Preservation and Use of Archival Materials in the Digital Age, has also been appended to the collection.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: In 1964, at the request of the U.S. Peace Corps, the Research Institute for the Study of Man (RISM) initiated a three-year epidemiological and ethnograpic research project in Bolivia.

Headed by Dr. Vera Rubin, RISM's founder and director, and Lambros Comitas, assistant director, the Project employed more than eighty social and medical scientists and assistants. Organized as teams, researchers lived in six rural communities. Each community represented a major organizational type, ranging from minimally stratified and nonpolitical to complex stratification and politically revolutionized. Four of the communities were situated in the rural towns of Villa Abecia, Coroico, Reyes and Sorata, and two were in the Indian pueblos of Compi and San Miguel (see map).

The region had been impacted by major social reform in 1952 when the Nationalist Revolutionary Movement (MNR) took power. New, politically mobilized campesinos from the rural Aymara and Quechua populations redistributed part of the country's national resources. The MNR made a number of efforts to integrate the society, which was stratified yet culturally heterogeneous and regionally oriented. Some of these most important efforts involved land reform, nationalization of the tin mines, establishment of institutional supports for the working population, and the dramatic expansion of rural education.

The project had two interrelated research objectives. The epidemiological team attempted to define the major problems of health and disease in rural Bolivian communities, taking into account the different ecological regions of the country. The ethnographic team delineated the major social features of each community by conducting a comparative study of social relations and social processes. Numerous volumes of ethnographic and sociological data were generated and subsequently used in comparative studies that included an extensive social survey of heads of households. This epidemiological and ethnographic research became fundamental to the planning of future community development programs and provided insight into the dynamics of community problems and community change.

However, the complexity of the research and analysis, as well as the interest in the application of scientific knowledge, resulted in more than a third of total project funding being provided by RISM. The methodological and theoretical development of the Project, as well as the research findings, were detailed in a report developed during the period of study. Quarterly reports, describing the work and the course of research, were filed with the Peace Corps. The epidemiological teams systematically sampled each community, and the results were entered into a database. The material was subsequently organized, analyzed, and used to prepare the final epidemiological report and summary of findings on health levels and health behavior. The final publication, Epidemiological Studies in Bolivia, was published in November 1967 and translated into Spanish ( Estudios Epidemiologicos en Bolivia) by the epidemiological research team.

The ethnographic report was published in 1969 as Changing Rural Bolivia and in 1971 by Oxford University Press as Changing Rural Society. In addition, a number of articles, reports, theses and doctoral dissertations resulted from the project research.

list.item: Preface, Changing Rural Bolivia: Final Anthropological Report for the Peace Corps. New York: Research Institute for the Study of Man, 1969.
Retrospect and Prospect: Preservation and Use of Archival Materials in the Digital Age. Exhibition of the RISM Bolivia Project 1964 - 1967.
"Theory and Methodology of the RISM Bolivia Project," unpublished Mss.

70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012

Fax: (212) 995-4225

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The Collection contains human subject data and unpublished manuscripts. Some material may be restricted.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The materials associated with the Bolivia Project were created by teams of epidemiological and ethnographic researchers between 1964 - 1967 and transferred to the New York University Archives in 2006.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of 5.5 linear feet of both incoming and outgoing correspondence relating to various phases of the project, arranged alphabetically by the correspondents' last names or subject matter. Also included in this series are final reports, telegrams, clippings, budget papers, notes, memorandum, film strips, articles, and curriculum vitae that are referenced in the correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These materials (Boxes 12-15) remain at the Reed Foundation. Please contact the Foundation for access to this series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of index cards that serve as a quick reference to the original field notes. The cards have been organized into four subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains approximately 5,300 biographical index cards compiled during the processing of ethnographic research materials. These cards do not include names, Community Househould Numbers, or Member of the Household Numbers. The index cards, organized by community, include an alphabetical arrangement of inteviewees, the initials of individual field workers, and page numbers from the original field notes.

did.unittitle: Compi Biographical Index Cards A - Z
Coroico Biographical Index Cards A - Z
Reyes Biographical Index Cards A - Z
San Miguel Biographical Index Cards A - Z
Sorata Biographical Index Cards A - Z
Villa Abecia Biographical Index Cards A - M
Villa Abecia Biographical Index Cards N - Z
Subseries B. CSO Indexed Field Notes Cards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains approximately 86,000 Community Study Outline (CSO) indexed field notecards. The cards are organized by community. The CSO index number is noted next to a bracket on the left side of each card, as are the initials of the field worker and the page of the original field notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series relate to the epidemiological study conducted between 1964 - 1967. They have been organized into 11 subseries that document the various research activies.
Please note that Subseries G-K, which are organized by community, may contain overlapping, combined data.

did.unittitle: Subseries A. Blood Examination Laboratory Processing Records

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of blood examination laboratory processing records. The material in this series was organized in manuscript form by Dr. Franz Ressel, head of epidemiological laboratory procedures in Bolivia. The test results were indexed by Member of the Household Number.

did.unittitle: Subseries B. Blood Samples: Blood Typing Cards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries B consists of 2,192 blood typing cards placed in archival polypropylene binders. The cards in this series, housed to minimize movement and moisture retention, were used for blood typing and indexed by the Member of the Household Number.

did.unittitle: Subseries C. Health Questionnaire / Cedula de Salud

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of 1,791 Health Questionnaires (cedulas de salud), organized by community. The Questionnaires were used as a preliminary census that documented the size of households and health conditions of family members. The Questionnaires contain the Community Household Number, written above the page numbers, and the name of the head of household, which may also appear in the existing Biographical Index Cards.

did.unittitle: Subseries D. Computer Generated Charts: Census and Distributions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of statistical charts based on the processed census information of the communities being studied.

did.unittitle: Epidemiological Studies in Bolivia Printed edition; offset master copy
Subseries E. Epidemiological Studies in Bolivia [Final Report]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of materials related to the final report published in 1967 as Epidemiological Studies in Bolivia in English and Spanish.

did.unittitle: RISM. Epidemiological Studies in Bolivia: Final Epidemiological Report for the Peace Corps. New York: RISM, 1967. (2 copies)
Omran, Abdel R., William J. McEwen, and Mahfouz Zaki. Estudios Epidemiologicos en Bolivia. New York: RISM, 1967. (2 copies)

Rubin, Jane Gregory, and Ariana Donalds, eds. Bread Made from Yuca. New York: Interamericas, 2003.
Miscellaneous box of unidentified negatives and slides

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of charts which were generated during the processing of epidemiological data. Organized by age and gender, the charts were included in the final report.
**NB: I have been unable to locate this subseries.

did.unittitle: Ascaris Lumbrocoides Charts Negative/Positive Results (61 pages organized in a binder)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of 703 cards in compound form that includes Household Sanitation information (Subseries H described below). The form includes the Community Household Number, which indexes the epidemiological study documents, and the name of the head of household, which may be included in the Biographical Index.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries describes the sanitation conditions of the various communities, including water supply, latrines, refuse and cleanliness, animals, and housing conditions. Subseries H records have been filed with those of Subseries G, Household Administrative Cards, and are organized by community.

did.unittitle: Subseries I. Investigation of Infant Feeding Habits (100)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of 100 forms comprising a survey of infant feeding habits in Sorata. The forms include the name of the individual being studied and may also appear in the Biographical Index.

did.unittitle: Subseries J. Laboratory Results/ Pruebas de Laboratorio

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of 5,534 records representating the data collected from 1,186 households in the six study communities, and the schoolchildren of Compi, Coroico, Reyes, LaPaz and Penas. The data is indexed by the Member of the Household Number.

did.unittitle: La Paz Centro de Salud Publica

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of 3,531 surveys documenting test results for members of 1,186 households in the communities noted in Subseries J. The forms include personal information of individuals and reactions to the tuberculin tests. The surveys are indexed by the Member of the Household Number.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series relate to the ethnographic study undertaken between 1964 and 1967. The final report was published in 1969 as Changing Rural Bolivia. The report was republished in 1971 by Oxford University Press as Changing Rural Society. The materials have been divided into five subseries.

did.unittitle: Subseries A. Household Structure Diagram/Bosquejo de Casa

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of 122 forms arranged by the name of the head of household. These documents are stored with the Household Administrative Card-Household Sanitation, Tuberculin Surveys, and Laboratory Results in the Epidemiological Research Material. The Household Structure Diagram was used to register information regarding kinship.

did.unittitle: Changing Rural Society manuscript and photos: Oxford University Press
Subseries C. Community Census/ Censo de la Comunidad

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of 161 census forms. This census, undertaken in San Miguel and Sorata, includes the names of the people interviewed, which may also be referenced in the Biographical Index. The census material also includes information about family members, language, education and status in the community.

did.unittitle: Subseries D. Community Study Outline (CSO)/ Bosquejo para el estudio de las Communidades

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of the Community Study Outline (CSO)/Bosquejo para el estudio de las communidades. The CSO is an outline that was used to standardize and index the information recorded in the field notes generated by each anthropologist. The one exception is Compi, where the anthropologists were already present in the community conducting their own research. For Compi, only Biographical Index and Member of Household Number designations exist. These forms document geographic environment, population demographics, history and development, institutional systems, the sociopolitical system, community and private health, and the Peace Corps program.

did.unittitle: Subseries E. Field Notes / Notas de Campo

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of 14,000 pages and 30 bound volumes of field notes, organized by community and fieldworker. The field notes were processed by a team of data coders and analysts, who produced the CSO Indexed Field Notes Cards and the Biographical Index.
Each fieldworker is identified by his or her initials. A list of fieldworkers by community may be found below.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series have been divided into two subseries.

did.unittitle: Subseries A. Attitudinal Questionnaire /Cedula de Creencias

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries A contains 229 Attitudinal Questionnaires/Cedulas de Creencias. These questionnaires have been organized by community and include the names of persons who were interviewed. These names may also appear in the Biographical Index.

did.unittitle: Subseries B. Household Social Survey / Encuesta sobre la Comunidad (1,094)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subseries B contains 1,094 Household Social Surveys/Encuestas sobre la Communidad. These surveys have not been fully analyzed or indexed with other materials in the collection. Some materials were processed and analyzed by Jonathan L. Kelley and Herbert S. Klein for their study Revolution and the Rebirth of Inequality, published in 1981.

did.unittitle: Series VII. Microfiche: CSO Indexed Field Note Cards
Microfiche: CSO Indexed Field Note Cards
Series VIII. Microfilm: Biographical Index Cards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series includes reports written by field investigators, proposals, quarterly reports sent to the Peace Corps, articles related to Bolivia, community studies, and reference materials, all arranged by author's last name. Please note that some reports are duplicated in Series I. Correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The materials in this series have been arranged alphabetically by author's name. This series has been organized into two subseries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The materials in this subseries consist of student papers prepared by students from Columbia University and the University of Kentucky. Students developed these papers during summer fieldwork studies conducted by by Dr. Lambros Comitas, Assistant Director of the Research Institute for the Study of Man.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Please be aware that FERPA guidelines may prevent access to student materials in the absence of a signed release form.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of 15 maps, arranged chronologically. Most of the maps in this series were hand drawn and provide details of the communities being studied. The maps were also used for planting purposes and for building.

did.unittitle: Plano General De La Comunidad "Tauca" Provinicia Omasuyos Canton Stgo De Huata
Plano General De La Comunidad "Tauca" Provinicia Omasuyos Canton Stgo De Huata

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of black-and-white and color photos of varying sizes and contact sheets in 2 photo albums. The pictures depict urban and rural landscapes, indigenous costumes, celebrations and festivals, musicians, market scenes, religious ceremonies, population and interaction between the indigenous population and members of the RISM epidemiology team. Among those credited with taking the photos are Kay Barnes and Victor Novick in Villa Abecia, William McEwen in Sorota, Herbert Klein in San Miguel, K. Barnes and D.B. Heath in Coroico, and Victor Novick in Reyes. Dr. Lambros Comitas provided general photo coverage. A number of photographs were contributed by Dr. Vera D. Rubin.

did.unittitle: Villa Abecia, Sorota, San Miguel, Coroico, Reyes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of 0.5 linear feet, arranged chronologically. This series contains articles, tables, charts and notes that relate to the Project's research goals. Some material is duplicated in Series I. Correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Partly as a result of the RISM Bolivia Project (1964-1967), the United States Office of Education in 1968 and 1969 sponsored a study of rural education in Argentina, Bolivia, and Jamaica. The principal investigator of this study was Lambros Comitas, then Professor of Anthropology and Education at Teachers College, Columbia University, and Associate Director of the Research Institute for the Study of Man.
The Bolivia CV Recordings, an integral part of this comparative study, were taped by Lambros Comitas in 1969 using a Sony Videocorder and CV reel-to-reel videotape for helican scan video recorders.
